interview_questions.question: What is the difference between <div> and <span>?
interview_questions.answer: <div> is a block-level element (starts new line, full width). <span> is an inline element (no new line, content width). Use <div> for layout sections and <span> for small text formatting.

interview_questions.question: Can you change an element from inline to block?
interview_questions.answer: Yes, using the CSS property 'display'. For example, display: block; or display: inline;.

practice_problems.problem: Create a blue box (div) containing two words, where one word is red (span).
practice_problems.hint: Style a div with color blue, nest a span with color red.

real_world_use_cases.description: CSS layouts rely on understanding the block model. We use divs to build the grid/flex structure and spans to style specific text bits.

exam_notes: Block: New line, Full width (div, p, h1)
Inline: No new line, content width (span, a, img)
summary: Understanding display types is fundamental to layout. Block elements (div) act as structural boxes that stack vertically, while inline elements (span) flow within text. Using the correct container is key to predictable styling.
